content: Scammers are copying on-line adds for homes that are for sale and offering them for moderate or low rent with a cash deposit up front ($1200-$2000). The Scammers say they are moving to some place out of America and need to rent the home immediately. The money is to be sent to some place like London - - The whole scam is operated on-line. IT was uncovered when a woman showed up at a house that was for sale, wanting to look it over before sending the deposit to begin renting. Of course, the family inside were taken aback. Though they had been trying to sell the home for two months, they had never considered renting it. When they looked at the Add the woman had, it was identical to theirs, external and internal pictures etc, except for the name and E-Mail address, via cut and paste . . . Luckily, the woman had sent no money - - Anybody heard of anything like this happening in their area? Wandering and Wondering
reply: Scammers are copying on-line adds for homes that are for sale and offering them for moderate or low rent with a cash deposit up front ($1200-$2000). content: quote: Originally posted by m551sheridan: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Scammers are copying on-line adds for homes that are for sale and offering them for moderate or low rent with a cash deposit up front ($1200-$2000). The Scammers say they are moving to some place out of America and need to rent the home immediately. The money is to be sent to some place like London - - The whole scam is operated on-line. IT was uncovered when a woman showed up at a house that was for sale, wanting to look it over before sending the deposit to begin renting. Of course, the family inside were taken aback. Though they had been trying to sell the home for two months, they had never considered renting it. When they looked at the Add the woman had, it was identical to theirs, external and internal pictures etc, except for the name and E-Mail address, via cut and paste . . . Luckily, the woman had sent no money - - Anybody heard of anything like this happening in their area? question... how could in/outside pictures be identical if not real? could it be that the current occupants are pulling this scam off themselves? Not outside realm of possibilities. What the scammer does is surf the legitimate on-line adds, copies the whole thing, pictures and all, then pastes his E-mail address and name over the original poster's, then puts it on a different site offering rentals. A really gullible person might see all the great pictures and send the money. In this case, the woman came to check it out first. That's when both the woman and the owners realized there was a scam in process. Better Business Bureau is digging into it - - Wandering and Wondering

content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Scammers are copying on-line adds for homes that are for sale and offering them for moderate or low rent with a cash deposit up front ($1200-$2000). The Scammers say they are moving to some place out of America and need to rent the home immediately. The money is to be sent to some place like London - - The whole scam is operated on-line. IT was uncovered when a woman showed up at a house that was for sale, wanting to look it over before sending the deposit to begin renting. Of course, the family inside were taken aback. Though they had been trying to sell the home for two months, they had never considered renting it. When they looked at the Add the woman had, it was identical to theirs, external and internal pictures etc, except for the name and E-Mail address, via cut and paste . . . Luckily, the woman had sent no money - - Anybody heard of anything like this happening in their area? Some of these people were trying to do this on Craig's List late last year when I was looking to move. The ad had pictures of the inside and the outside of the property, and the ad was written in proper English (at least it read like it was written by an American), and the address, but something wasn't right. The rental price being asked for a property in the area I wanted seemed too low for the house, so I inquired, just to see what would happen. The reply back used a completely different grammar pattern - clearly written by a foreigner. The person said he was moving out of country and wanted a money order. At that point, I knew it was a scam, but wanted to see how far it would go. So, I demanded to see the property before I rented it. The person said he couldn't meet me there. So I asked how I was supposed to get the keys, and how he could insure that the property had been inspected, maintained, and was up to code for renting. I asked him if he'd registered his rental property with the county. I asked for his phone number. I received one more "tap-dancing" e-mail from him, at which point I sent back a very short e-mail, calling him a scammer, telling him that I'd found the original ad for the property listed by the real owners, and told him to screw himself. But yeah, they're doing this in several locations. The only thing individuals can do is to post "watch out for these scams!" ads on Craig's List, and hope that potential renters read the warnings. Oh, and harassing the scammers can be fun, too. Use an e-mail address not connected to anything useful.

The rental price being asked for a property in the area I wanted seemed too low for the house, so I inquired, just to see what would happen. The reply back used a completely different grammar pattern - clearly written by a foreigner. The person said he was moving out of country and wanted a money order. At that point, I knew it was a scam, but wanted to see how far it would go. So, I demanded to see the property before I rented it. The person said he couldn't meet me there. So I asked how I was supposed to get the keys, and how he could insure that the property had been inspected, maintained, and was up to code for renting. I asked him if he'd registered his rental property with the county. I asked for his phone number. I received one more "tap-dancing" e-mail from him, at which point I sent back a very short e-mail, calling him a scammer, telling him that I'd found the original ad for the property listed by the real owners, and told him to screw himself. But yeah, they're doing this in several locations. The only thing individuals can do is to post "watch out for these scams!" ads on Craig's List, and hope that potential renters read the warnings. Oh, and harassing the scammers can be fun, too. Use an e-mail address not connected to anything useful.

content: Greywolf, I don't think it's that new of a scam. Here in the NY/NJ metro area you occasionally hear about folks pulling similar stunts. What scammers do here is look for a sub-lease apartment or house, then turn around & list the apartment as if it was theirs. They take deposits from several people. THen all these people show up to "move in" only to find other people ready to move in also.
reply: Greywolf, I don't think it's that new of a scam. Here in the NY/NJ metro area you occasionally hear about folks pulling similar stunts. What scammers do here is look for a sub-lease apartment or house, then turn around & list the apartment as if it was theirs. They take deposits from several people. THen all these people show up to "move in" only to find other people ready to move in also.

content: Ya know I didn't even remember it until I read Elesso's post just now, but when I first got to NC I almost bought into a scam. It was a NICE house that should've rented for about $1300 a month, and the guy (Indian or Pakistani) was a Doctor moving to Michigan cuz his wife wanted to go "home" and left ahead of him, leaving him behind to rent out the house. He was there and showed me the house, but it struck me as odd that there was 5 other people sleeping on the floor when I showed up (it was 10am!!) despite the fact that the place was fully furnished and even still had little girls clothing in the closets and toothbrushes in the bathroom! Ummm, if your wife moved (with your child) to Michigan to await you, wouldn't she pack her kids clothes?! Then there was the locked "office" downstairs, where he said he was keeping some things he couldn't take & didn't want disturbed. I was paying for a 4bed I could only use 3bed's of! To top it off, he wanted $850 a month, and was leaving the next day for Michigan and wanted me to give him the App. right then (with our SSN's on it, for a "credit check" he said) and then on payday when I had the Rent & Deposit, mail it to him in Michigan and he'd mail me the keys. Uh, NOOOOO thanks! Well come to find out the name he introduced himself with was a totally different name (and gender!) than the name on the address that was emailing me about the house when I inquired. He then later called me from Michigan to try and talk me out of turning the house down, and that number was a landline in ANOTHER name. He had told me they bought the house in 2007....Zillow showed it was bought in 2002, right after it was built...hmmm I drove by the house last week, to see what was up with it....it has Repo stickers on the windows and a Banks FOR SALE sign.

content: We had one not too long ago were the scammers somehow got the names of people's kids that had taken Advance Placement tests. They were telling the parents of the kids that they had won or qualified for a full-ride scholarship to a big-time university, but the needed to send a processing fee... The creeps went from district to district with these phone calls to numerous parents. I don't know if the authorities caught up with them, but it just shows how heartless and greedy these bassturds are! Yep, they should burn in hell!! Wandering and Wondering
